columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the different ratios needed based on the given data.

The current ratio refers to the ratio between the total current assets and total current liabilities of the given firm. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total current assets}}{\text{Total current liabilities}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,603,218}{\$3,507,909}\\[15 pt]
&=0.742
\end{aligned}$$

The current ratio of the firm is $0.742$. It is close to the lower quartile in the industry.

The quick ratio refers to the cash and accounts receivable over the total current liabilities. It measures the firm's ability to fulfill its short-term obligations. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quick ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Cash}+\text{Accounts receivable}}{\text{Total current liabilities}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$524,963+\$843,094}{\$3,507,909}\\[15 pt]
&=0.390
\end{aligned}$$

The quick ratio of the firm is $0.390$ which is higher than the median for this industry.

The cash ratio refers to the ratio between the firm's cash and the total current liabilities. It measures the liquidity of the company which is their ability to pay for the liabilities using their cash. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Cash}}{\text{Total current liabilities}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$524,963}{\$3,507,909}\\[15 pt]
&=0.150
\end{aligned}$$

The cash ratio of the firm is $0.150$ which is higher than the lower quartile but lower than the median.

The total asset turnover refers to the ratio between the total sales and the average total assets of the company. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total asset turnover}&=\dfrac{\text{Sales}}{\text{Total current assets}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$46,298,115}{\$2,603,218}\\[15 pt]
&=17.78
\end{aligned}$$

The total asset turnover is $17.78$ which is significantly higher than the upper quartile in the industry.

Inventory turnover refers to the ratio between the cost of goods sold and the inventory. This measures the rate at which the inventory is sold, replaced, or used. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inventory turnover}&=\dfrac{\text{Cost of goods sold}}{\text{Inventory}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$34,536,913}{\$1,235,161}\\[15 pt]
&=27.82
\end{aligned}$$

The inventory turnover is $27.82$ which is also significantly higher than the upper quartile.

Receivables turnover is similar to the inventory turnover but it measures the ratio between the sales and the accounts receivable of the company. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Receivables turnover}&=\dfrac{\text{Sales}}{\text{Accounts receivable}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$46,298,115}{\$843,094}\\[15 pt]
&=54.91
\end{aligned}$$

The receivables turnover ratio for this company is $54.91$ which is again significantly higher than the border for upper quartile in this industry.

The total debt ratio measures the ability of the company to fulfill its long-term obligations. It is the ratio between the difference in total assets and total equity over the total assets. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total assets}-\text{Total equity}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$22,985,163-\$13,177,254}{\$22,985,163}\\[15 pt]
&=0.427
\end{aligned}$$

The total debt ratio of the company is $0.427$ which is very close to the lower quartile in the industry.

The debt-equity ratio refers to the ability of the company to pay for their debt including the interest and inflation. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Debt-equity ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Long term debt}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$6,300,000}{\$13,177,254}\\[15 pt]
&=0.478
\end{aligned}$$

The debt-equity ratio of the company is $0.478$ which is at the low-end in this industry. 
\end{aligned}$$

The equity multiplier refers to the part of the company's assets that is financed by the investors. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity multiplier}&=\dfrac{\text{Total assets}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$22,985,163}{\$13,177,254}\\[15 pt]
&=1.744
\end{aligned}$$

The equity multiplier for this company is $1.744$ which is at the lower end for this industry

Times interest earned refers to the company's ability to pay for the interest of their current outstanding debt. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Times interest earned}&=\dfrac{\text{Earning before interest and tax}}{\text{Interest}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$3,815,484}{\$725,098}\\[15 pt]
&=5.26
\end{aligned}$$

The times interest earned in the company is $5.26$ which is slightly higher than the lower quartile.

The cash coverage ratio refers to the company's ability to pay for its long-term obligations while still generating cash. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash coverage ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Earnings before interest and tax}+\text{Depreciation}}{\text{Interest}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$3,815,484+\$2,074,853}{\$725,098}\\[15 pt]
&=8.124
\end{aligned}$$

The cash coverage ratio is $8.124$ which is close to the median value for this industry.

The profit margin is a percentage value that measures the company's net income per sales. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profit margin}&=\dfrac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Sales}} \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,317,789}{\$46,298,115} \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=5.01\%
\end{aligned}$$

The profit margin is $5.01\%$ which is close to the median value

The return on assets refers to the percentage value that measures the ratio between the net income and the total assets. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Return on assets}&=\dfrac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Total assets}}\times 100\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,317,789}{\$22,985,163}\times 100\\[15 pt]
&=10.08\%
\end{aligned}$$

The return on assets is $10.08\%$ which is higher than the median value of the industry.

Finally, the return on equity refers to the profitability of an investor's holding in the company. It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Return on equity}&=\dfrac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Total equity}}
 \times 100\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,317,789}{\$13,177,254}\times 100\\[15 pt]
&=17.59\%
\end{aligned}$$

The return on equity is $17.59\%$ which is higher than the median value of the industry.
